conclusion: Determine the dynamic friction factor between the ground and the logs.
Each log is in static equilibrium, so the sum of the forces and the sum of the moments about any point must be zero.
Normal force exerted by the ground on each log is \( F_N = mg \).
Let \( \mu \) be the dynamic friction factor between the ground and the logs.
The weight of each log is \( mg \).
For log \( A \), the weight is \( mg \), normal forces from logs \( B \) and \( C \) are \( F_{NB} \) and \( F_{NC} \), frictional forces from the ground are \( f_A \) and \( f_B \).
For log \( B \), the weight is \( mg \), normal forces from logs \( A \) and \( C \) are \( F_{NA} \) and \( F_{NC} \), frictional force from the ground is \( f_B \).
For log \( C \), the weight is \( mg \), normal force from log \( B \) is \( F_{NB} \), frictional force from the ground is \( f_C \).
The angle between the section center lines is \( \angle O_1 = 120^\circ \).
The angle between the lines of action of the normal forces \( F_{NB} \) and \( F_{NC} \) is \( 120^\circ \).
The sum of the moments about the center of log \( A \) must be zero: \( mgR = F_{NB}R \cos(60^\circ) + F_{NC}R \cos(60^\circ) \).
For log \( B \), \( mgR = F_{NA}R \cos(60^\circ) + F_{NC}R \cos(60^\circ) \).
The maximum static frictional force is \( f = \mu F_N \).
For log \( A \), the frictional force \( f_A \) must balance the component of the weight of log \( A \) that is parallel to the ground: \( f_A = \mu mg \).
Since \( f_A \) must be equal to the component of the weight of log \( A \) that is parallel to the ground, \( \mu mg = mg \sin(60^\circ) \).
